Jonathan Oddy wrote:
> Dear all
> 
> I've been TDD come code, which is fine; I've a number of tests that show
> the code to be working how I'd expect.  I've now come to add some more
> code within another (set of) class(es).  In doing so I note some
> commonality between this and the old code, so have abstracted it.  The
> old code still works - I know this because of its unit tests.  Now the
> question should I (at point of extraction) move/create a set of tests
> for the extracted functionality?  Initially (pragmatically) I think not
> because the extraction is due to hygienic reasons and the code is
> already covered (as I am testing the behaviour of class A - the fact it
> now uses class B seems irrelevant) and I don't have time (the usual
> caveat) to do this... 
> 
> And yet if I'd hit upon the need for this extraction earlier in the
> process I'd have written B first along with a set of tests then written
> A to use B and injected a fake B into A to drive its tests.  So from
> that standpoint the later would have resulted in better unit test
> coverage than the former.
> 
> How do other people handle this type of refactoring and unit test
> management and what they do?

As B grows, you'll start to add tests for B on its own, which will make 
it easier to notice that some of its tests are here and others are 
there. If this becomes a problem -- and it isn't always -- that's the 
point at which I'd start moving tests.

Now it seems that A instantiates B directly, based on your description. 
If that's true, then I would consider refactoring A to allow me to 
inject B into it, and see how the tests would change. Perhaps YAGNI, and 
as you say, you need to spend your time on other things; however, my 
designs have always suffered from too /many/ hardcoded dependencies, and 
not too /few/.
